hed: You’re Zipping Your Jacket the Wrong Way
dek: For years you’ve been fooled into thinking that there’s only one way to zip a jacket—from the bottom to the top. Maybe it’s due to America’s ever-expanding waistline, but these days there’s a new innovation in the outerwear game: the two-way zipper, unzipped at the bottom. It’s the quickest way to ease up your vibe and keep your jacket from bunching up awkwardly around your waist. Though the look can be traced back to Los Angeles in the ’90s, these days there’s no tank top or bandanna required. All you need is the right hardware, and the right attitude.

items.title: How to Wear It
items.caption: All you have to do to make the look work is wear it with confidence. If you’re new to it, stick with a classic MA-1 bomber in an army-ready color, then pair it with your best suit pants and dress shoes.

items.title: The Extreme Stance
items.caption: Of course, unzipping almost all the way to the top (as recommended here by L.A. streetwear label Fear of God) also looks rad and opens up a world of potential, layering-wise.

items.title: John Elliott
items.caption: But this swerve doesn't just work with bombers. Any jacket with two-way capabilities can and should be utilized.

items.title: Y-3
items.caption: Wearing white under your double-zip jacket will help break up a matching track suit.

items.title: The Subtle Swerve
items.caption: If you’re not ready yet for the full turn, start simple by unzipping the bottom just a few inches. It’s an easy move that will drastically crank up your fall style, especially when your expert layering makes things start to feel a little snug.

items.title: AMI
items.caption: Don’t stop with hoodies, though. A turtleneck worn under your bomber will give you two advanced moves in one simple fall look.

items.title: Jason Statham
items.caption: The double-zip action looks so good, in fact, that even a guy who's famous for driving cars in movies would prefer to walk the streets when wearing it.

items.title: No Zippers Required
items.caption: The thing about this move is that it’s mostly about the layering and comfort, meaning you can do it even if you’re using old-school jacket-fastening technology.

socialTitle: You're Zipping Your Jacket the Wrong Way
